description.summary: Brazilian Amazon dolphin-people shapeshifters. Pink river dolphins transform into beautiful humans at night, wear hats to hide blowholes, seduce people at parties, and lure victims to their underwater kingdom called Encante.
description.full: The Encantado are shapeshifting beings from Brazilian Amazon folklore who live as dolphins (usually pink river dolphins) but transform into beautiful humans at night. In human form, they appear as handsome men or beautiful women who are perfect dancers and party-goers, but they must always wear hats to hide their blowholes. They emerge from rivers during festivals and parties to seduce humans, with male Encantado often impregnating women and female Encantado seducing men. They may lure people to their underwater kingdom known as Encante. Unexplained pregnancies in Amazonian communities are traditionally blamed on Encantado, and children born under mysterious circumstances may be said to bear the Encantado's mark. Out of respect, river dolphins should never be called 'dolphins' but rather 'boto,' and it is dangerous to make eye contact with them during festivals. The Encantado represent the mystery and allure of the Amazon rivers and embody both indigenous and Portuguese cultural influences.

etymology.meaning: Enchanted being; one who enchants or is enchanted

related_phenomena.name: Each-uisge
related_phenomena.description: Scottish water horse that transforms and drowns victims

dolphin_form.species: Pink river dolphin (Inia geoffrensis) usually, but any river dolphin

features.description: Must always wear hat to cover blowhole
Perfect dancers, life of the party
Dolphin blowhole on top of head (must be hidden)

human_form.morphology: Beautiful human form, perfectly proportioned, but must keep head covered to hide blowhole

abilities.description: Transform from dolphin to human at night
Irresistible charm and beauty, especially at parties
Outstanding dancing skills that attract attention
Can lure humans to underwater kingdom
Male Encantado can impregnate human women

behavior.diet: Unknown in human form; fish as dolphin
patterns: Transform at night for parties and festivals
May impregnate women or lure people underwater
Always wear hats to hide blowhole

range.description: Amazon river basin in Brazil and neighboring countries. Wherever pink river dolphins are found.

first_recorded.source: Amazonian oral traditions with indigenous and Portuguese influences

peak_activity_periods.description: Active in Amazonian folklore from colonial times to present
Most active during parties and celebrations

temporal.seasonal_patterns: More active during festival seasons and celebrations

origins.cultural_roots: Brazilian Amazon folklore, blending indigenous Amazonian beliefs with Portuguese colonial influences
origins.earliest_accounts: Oral traditions from colonial and post-colonial periods
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to global shapeshifter traditions and water spirit folklore

timeline.significance: Indigenous Amazonians had spiritual relationships with river dolphins
Portuguese 'encantado' concept merges with indigenous beliefs
Remains active part of Amazonian culture and dolphin conservation

history.modern_era: The Encantado remains deeply embedded in Amazonian culture. Unexplained pregnancies are still sometimes attributed to Encantado, and respect for river dolphins ('boto') continues. The legend plays a role in dolphin conservation, as harming a boto is considered dangerous and disrespectful.

paranormal.name: Spiritual entity
paranormal.description: Genuine shapeshifting beings from Amazonian cosmology

skeptical.name: Social explanation for pregnancy
skeptical.description: Cultural mechanism to explain illegitimate pregnancies without shame

skeptical.name: Cultural synthesis myth
skeptical.description: Blend of indigenous river dolphin reverence with Portuguese 'enchanted' concepts

skeptical.name: Conservation folklore
skeptical.description: Stories that promote protection of endangered river dolphins

stories: Handsome stranger at party is revealed to be Encantado when hat falls off
Women become pregnant by mysterious lover who disappears by dawn
People lured to underwater kingdom never return
Never make eye contact with dolphins during festivals
folklore.beliefs: The Encantado are real beings deserving respect. Never call river dolphins 'dolphins' - use 'boto' instead. Unexplained pregnancies are often attributed to Encantado seduction.

indigenous.significance: Central to Amazonian cultural identity; promotes respect for river dolphins; provides social explanation for complex situations
indigenous.sensitivity_note: The Encantado is part of living Amazonian culture. These are not merely stories but active folklore that serves social and conservation functions.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Acknowledge Amazonian cultural ownership. Understand the social function of these stories. Respect river dolphin conservation connected to folklore.

research.ongoing_studies: Study of Amazonian folklore by Brazilian anthropologists and folklorists; river dolphin conservation efforts linked to cultural beliefs
